headline: COVID-19 kills over 168,000 in Africa with 5.8 recoveries
summarized_story:
Angela OnwuzooOver 168,000 people have died of COVID-19 on the African continent since the outbreak of the viral infection, according to the Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention.
The Africa CDC says more than 6.6m COVID-19 cases have been recorded on the continent so far with over 5.8m recoveries.
East Africa, according to the report, recorded 794,410 cases; 16,837 deaths, and 710,420 recoveries with Ethiopia leading the region with 279,629 cases; 4,381 deaths, and 263,392 recoveries.
In Northern Africa, there are now 1,914,653 cases; 53,806 deaths, and 1,608,035 recoveries while Morocco has the highest figures with 606,871 cases; 9,697 deaths, and 552,983 recoveries.
I urge African countries to gear up and get ready, as our drought is finally ending.”Copyright PUNCHAll rights reserved.

headline: Ward congress: Lagos APC holds stakeholders’ meeting
summarized_story:
By Olasunkanmi AkoniAhead of the ward congress of the party scheduled for Saturday, July, 31, Lagos State chapter of All Progressives Congress,APC, has held a statewide stakeholders’ meeting across the 20 Local Governments and 37 Local Council Development Areas, LCDAS.
The meeting was sequel to the directive of the National Caretaker Committee to bring all party leaders and members together to rub minds on the forthcoming congresses towards achieving cohesion and acceptable consensus.
The various meetings agreed on the desirability of a consensus arrangement that will consider all interests and unite the party towards count-down to the next national elections.
According to Caretaker Publicity Secretary of the state party, Mr Seye Oladejo, the carnival like meetings urged all members to participate actively in the congresses and uphold party discipline at all times.

headline: INTELS graduates 11th Batch of women empowerment scheme
summarized_story:
By Godwin OritseIN a bid to enhance its Corporate Social Responsibility, CSR,Nigerua’s oil and gas logistics giant, INTELS Nigeria Limited has graduated 34 beneficiaries of the 11th Batch of its flagship women development programme popularly known as the Women Empowerment Programme Scheme Synergy (WEPSS).
The graduation of the 11th Batch brings the total number of beneficiaries in the popular women empowerment scheme to 1,500.
WEPSS was established by INTELS in 2013 to empower 5,000 Nigerian women over a 20-year period through training in fashion design and tailoring.
They were all given start-up tailoring equipment and kits donated by INTELS to kick-start their fashion businesses.
An excited Praise-Jah Ufot, who also received an industrial sewing machine in additional to other tailoring items, commended INTELS for “positively changing” her life and the lives of other beneficiaries of the empowerment scheme.

headline: Taraba residents groan over bad roads, drainages in capital city
summarized_story:
Vehicular movement in Jalingo, the capital of Taraba, is no doubt presently becoming cumbersome due to absence of motorable roads and drainage.
A cross section of the residents, who spoke with DAILY POST today in Jalingo metropolis, said the situation has made it impossible for them to ply the various roads leading to their houses.
The residents, who cited Gombe State that was created after Taraba as an example, said tarred roads and drainages are lucidly absent in most parts of their city.
More to the displeasure of Jalingo residents is the absence of street lights, a situation which they believe often make it possible for hoodlums to carry out their attacks uninterrupted.
A visit to the premises of the Taraba State Road Maintenance Agency, indicated that like the Jalingo residents, it also needs infrastructural attention.

headline: Nnamdi Kanu seeks speedy trial of treasonable felony charges despite court vacation
summarized_story:
Nnamdi Kanu, leader of the proscribed Indigenous Peoples of Biafra (IPOB), has formally applied for speedy trial of the treasonable felony charges brought against him by the Nigerian government.
DAILY POST gathered that Kanu’s action may not be unconnected with his wish to be moved out of the detention facility of the Department of the State Service DSS after an order by trial judge, Justice Binta Nyako.
Dependable government officials told our correspondent that there was nothing urgent in the charges to warrant the federal government seeking the prosecution of the defendant during court vacation.
DAILY POST was also told that the justice ministry has opted to be meticulous and follow sequence order in the trial rather than disrupting the vacation calendar of the court.
The Federal Government counsel, Mr Mrohammed Abubakar, of the Federal Ministry of Justice could not be reached for comments on the issue.

headline: COVID-19: Again, UAE Extends Travel Ban Against Nigeria, S’Africa

headline: Anxiety as Cholera kills 169 Kano residents, 5,221 infected

headline: Nigeria Records Highest Daily COVID-19 Cases In Almost Five Months
summarized_story:
The figure was reported by the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) in its latest update on the outbreak of the disease in the country.
Data from the NCDC – the Federal Government agency responsible for the control of disease outbreaks – revealed that the figure reported on July 29 was the highest in almost five months.
The last time Nigeria reported a daily figure higher than 558 was on March 4, 2021, when a total of 708 cases were confirmed.
Amid fears that the country was already slipping into the third wave of the pandemic, Lagos State reported 376 new infections.
As Nigeria’s confirmed cases continue to rise with fears and panic from citizens, authorities have yet to officially declare a third wave of the pandemic.

headline: Hushpuppi: IGP Orders Review Of Allegations Against Abba Kyari
summarized_story:
The Inspector-General of Police, Usman Baba, has ordered an “internal review of the allegations” against a Deputy Commissioner of Police, Abba Kyari, by a United States Court.
Kyari also allegedly sent Hushpuppi bank account details for an account into which Hushpuppi could deposit payment for Vincent’s arrest and imprisonment.
Mr Kyari, in a Facebook post on Thursday, denied the allegations.
“Nobody demanded a kobo from Abbas Hushpuppi,” Mr Kyari said.
The clothes “were brought to our office and he sent somebody to collect them in our office,” Mr Kyari said.

headline: Buni’s Appointment As APC Chair Does Not Violate 1999 Constitution, Says Omo-Agege
summarized_story:
Senator Omo-Agege, who represents Delta State Central senatorial district and doubles as the Deputy President of the Senate, believes the law does not forbid a sitting governor from holding another position.
This was in reaction to the controversy over the appointment of Yobe State Governor, Mai Mala Buni, as the Chairman of the National Caretaker Committee of the All Progressives Congress (APC).
On Wednesday, the Supreme Court affirmed Governor Rotimi Akeredolu of the APC as the winner of the October 2020 governorship election in Ondo State.
The appellants had asked the court to sack Governor Akeredolu, saying his nomination form was signed by a sitting governor.
But in his legal opinion as a lawyer, Senator Omo-Agege disagreed with the position of the opposition party.

headline: Djokovic loses bid for Golden slam in Tokyo semi finals
summarized_story:
Novak Djokovic’s search for a historic ‘Golden Slam’ has come to an after his loss to Alexander Zverev at Tokyo 2020.
He was bidding to become the first men’s player to win a ‘Golden Slam’ — consisting of four grand slams and an Olympic gold medal in the same calendar year.
After the match, Zverev explained what he and Djokovic said as the pair embraced at the net.
“I told him that he’s the greatest of all time, and he will be,” Zverev told reporters.
AdvertisementZverev, 24, will now meet the Russian Olympic Committee’s Karen Khachanov in the gold medal match this weekend.

headline: NHRC to integrate formal, traditional justice systems to achieve peace in North East
summarized_story:
The executive secretary of the National Human Rights Commission, Tony Ojukwu is hoping to integrate the formal and traditional justice systems in a bid to achieve sustainable peace in conflict-affected areas in the country.
He stated this during a stakeholders consultative meeting on promoting reconciliation, reintegration and transitional justice in Borno, Adamawa and Yobe states.
The northeastern states have been hotbeds of insurgency in the last ten years, and the NHRC is hoping the move will help achieve sustainable peace in the region.

headline: Trending: Abba Kyari Indicted In Hushpuppi’s Fraud Case
summarized_story:
Reactions continue to trail the indictment of Nigeria’s Deputy Commissioner of Police, Abba Kyari, in the HushPuppi internet fraud case.
This is coming after a US court issued a warrant of arrest for Kyari over his role in a series of fraud committed by notorious internet fraudster, Ramon Abbas aka Hushpuppi.
Meanwhile, a video of a Nigerian federal lawmaker, Honourable Ibrahim Abunna spraying money on members of his constituency has made the rounds.
The lawmaker who represents Mafa, Dikwa and Konduga federal constituency, Borno state, in the House of Representatives threw wads of cash from his balcony.

headline: Tokyo 2020: Djokovic’s Golden Slam Bid Dashed, Loses to Zverev in Semis
summarized_story:
There will be no Golden Slam for Novak Djokovic.
The top-ranked Serb lost to Alexander Zverev of Germany 1-6, 3-6, 6-1 Friday in the semifinals of the tennis tournament at the Tokyo Olympics.
Djokovic was attempting to become the first man to win all four Grand Slam tournaments and Olympic gold in the same year.
Steffi Graf in 1988 remains the only tennis player to achieve the Golden Slam.
The Russian beat Pablo Carreno Busta of Spain 6-3, 6-3.

headline: Russian Module Mishap Destabilises International Space Station
summarized_story:
The International Space Station (ISS) was destabilised after engines of a newly-arrived Russian module inadvertently fired up, officials say.
US and Russian officials said that the seven crew members aboard the space station were never in any danger.
Communications with the ISS crew were lost for several minutes during the incident.

In addition, the module carries with it a large robotic arm (ERA) supplied by the European Space Agency (Esa).

headline: Eritrean Refugees Demand Protection Amid Tigray War
summarized_story:
Eritrean refugees have organised a protest in front of the UN refugee agency (UNHCR) office in the capital, Addis Ababa, demanding the relocation of thousands of refugees from camps in the war-torn Tigray region.
“We want the world to know that Eritrean refugees are suffering in Ethiopia,” Miku Digaffe, one of the organisers of the rally, told Al Jazeera.
The UNHCR said this week that conditions for the refugees in Tigray have become increasingly dire, with about 24,000 Eritrean refugees trapped in the two camps in Tigray.
The UN has said the war would affect about 55,000 Eritrean refugees sheltered in the Afar region that borders Tigray.
The war and its trauma have made Ethiopia no longer a safe place for Eritrean refugees.

summarized_story:
South Africa’s Tatjana Schoenmaker was the star of the day, setting the first individual swimming world record at the Tokyo Olympics on Thursday.
It was the third world record at the Tokyo Aquatics Centre, with the first two coming in women’s relays.
The Australians have won four individual women’s events at the Tokyo Aquatics Centre, in addition to setting a world record in a 4×100 free relay that included both McKeon and Campbell.
